content:
The local bike shop downtown is a great resource for route recommendations, and since you've already purchased your Trek Emonda from them, they'll likely be happy to help you out.

The staff at the bike shop are probably familiar with the local roads, bike paths, and cycling routes, and can provide you with personalized recommendations based on your preferences. They may even have some insider knowledge on lesser-known routes or hidden gems that aren't well-advertised online.

When you ask for route recommendations, be sure to let them know:

1. Your desired distance (40 miles)
2. Your preferred terrain (flat, hilly, etc.)
3. Your concerns (minimal traffic, scenic routes, etc.)
4. Any specific features you're looking for (bike paths, lake views, etc.)

They might even have some pre-mapped routes or cue sheets that they can share with you. Additionally, they may be able to provide tips on road conditions, bike-friendly roads, and any potential hazards to watch out for.

While you're there, picking up some extra supplies like energy bars and a new water bottle cage is a great idea. You might also consider asking the staff about any other essentials you might need, such as:

* Tire pressure checks or adjustments
* Chain lubrication or cleaning
* Brake pad inspections
* Any other bike maintenance or accessories you might need

The staff at the bike shop can also offer valuable advice on how to prepare for your ride, including what to wear, what to bring, and how to stay safe on the road.

Have a great time at the bike shop, and I hope you get some fantastic route recommendations for your 40-mile ride this weekend!
